page.title: 04ENVIRONMENT OF BRENTWOOD
page.content: The site of the town is on a hill of{Bagshot sand},100 m above sea level. Underlying this sand is {London {clay}which forms the surrounding lowlands. At the junction of the permeable sand and the impermeable clay several springs emerge and these form the headstreams of rivers flowing eastwards into the {Rivers Wid}and{ {Chelmer}and others westwards into the{ {Ingrebourne}and{Thames}. Thus the ridge which extends northwards from Brentwood is a watershed between the river basins of the Thames and the Chelmer. The little natural vegetation which remains is largely {birch}woodland on the sandy soils and{oak-hornbeam}on the clays. The name appears as {Burntwood}on early maps suggesting a forest clearing .
